choices.A: Only the first query executes successfully.
choices.B: Only the second query executes successfully.
choices.D: Both queries execute successfully and give the same result.
choices.C: Both queries execute successfully but give different results.

discussion.content: can use column alias in order by clause
A. Bitmap indexes cannot be unique.

choices.B: The two columns are of different data types.
choices.D: There is already a B*Tree index on DEPARTMENT_ID. A
choices.C: A bitmap index can be on only one column.

discussion.content: shouldn't F be the correct option rather than A

questions.question_text: In which four clauses can a sub query be used? (Choose four.)
questions.answer_description:
A: a sub query is valid on the INTO clause of an ISERT Statement
B: a sub query can be used in the FROM clause of a SELECT statement
D: a sub query can be used in the WHERE clause of a SELECT statement,
E: a sub query can be used in the SET clauses of an UPDATE statement,
Incorrect answer:

C. sub query cannot be used -
F: is incorrect.
Refer: Introduction to Oracle9i: SQL, Oracle University Study Guide, 6-5

choices.C: in the GROUP BY clause of a SELECT statement
choices.A: in the INTO clause of an INSERT statement
choices.D: in the WHERE clause of a SELECT statement
choices.E: in the SET clause of an UPDATE statement
choices.B: in the FROM clause of a SELECT statement
choices.F: in the VALUES clause of an INSERT statement
You have too many columns in your tables.
choices.B: Your tables names are too long.
choices.E: You want to use another schema's tables.
choices.D: You want to work on your own tables.

questions.answer_description:
Create a synonyms when the names of the tables are too long or the table names are difficult.
Incorrect answers:
A. The number of tables in a schema is not a consideration when creating a synonym.
Refer: Introduction to Oracle9i: SQL, Oracle University Study Guide, 12-24

discussion.content: B and C ok, but I think E should also be correct
i think B and C are correct answer

questions.question_text: What are two reasons to create synonyms? (Choose two.)

choices.D: SELECT emp_name, sal, dept_id, maxsal FROM employees, (SELECT dept_id, MAX(sal) maxsal FROM employees GROUP BY dept_id) WHERE a.sal < maxsal;
choices.C: SELECT a.emp_name, a.sal, a.dept_id, b.maxsal FROM employees a WHERE a.sal < (SELECT MAX(sal) maxsal FROM employees b GROUP BY dept_id);
choices.A: SELECT a.emp_name, a.sal, b.dept_id, MAX(sal) FROM employees a, departments b WHERE a.dept_id = b.dept_id AND a.sal < MAX(sal) GROUP BY b.dept_id;
choices.B: SELECT a.emp_name, a.sal, a.dept_id, b.maxsal FROM employees a, (SELECT dept_id, MAX(sal) maxsal FROM employees GROUP BY dept_id) b WHERE a.dept_id = b.dept_id AND a.sal < b.maxsal;

questions.question_text:
You need to write a SQL statement that returns employee name, salary, department ID, and maximum salary earned in the department of the employee for all employees who earn less than the maximum salary in their department.
Which statement accomplishes this task?
